column3: NACK. This makes a number of policies harder to implement for the sake of a "simpler" (and less competent) default policy. I'm working on a mempool size cap that doesn't break policy freedom so completely.\n
Can you be more specific about which policies become harder to implement?\n
Priority-sorted area followed by fee/kB-sorted area (the previous default policy) would be the most obvious one. The policy before that (gradually higher min fee/kB as blocks are filled) as well.\n
@luke-jr Read the code.  You can implement such a policy with fee deltas.\n

Concept ACK, will review code and test later.

I've looked into policy stuff myself, and fee-delta methods make the most sense to me.

I actually like the concept of priority, which means that coinage can be used to "pay" for fees as a spam prevention.  The "production rate" of coinage is bounded, which means that one can set a minimum priority for transactions and a certain reserved size in each block and be ensured that, on average, all free transactions fit in this reserved block space forever.  I think that's a nice feature o

Concept ACK, I think the illusion that miners will mine TXs with 0 fee and high priority should be burned to the ground.\n\nno matter what the blocksize debat does we'll eventually end up with fees being a significant part of miner revenue and I don't see miners maintaining the high priority policy at that point, might as well get rid of the code for it and since you're keeping some of the priorit
#6584 solves my nit here (and is rebased). It also includes #6445.\nThat of course means I utACK this one, I just prefer my version (where I remove `GetMinRelayFee()`).\n
The effort of frequent rebasing isn't worth keeping this open.\n

@jgarzik is there any consensus on the change?  It seems wrong to close this unless the concept has been rejected? \n@laanwj if I were to pick up this PR,  would it be worth keeping open in light of #6584?\n
As a general principle, we probably don't want big pull requests to linger for a long time.  This is straightforward to regenerate.\n
@jgarzik Is there an issue for this?\n
@pstratem Good point - an issue would probably be appropriate, linking to this outdated branch as an example.\n

If GetMinRelayFee returns 0 this error only triggers when new coins are being created, which is checked later in Consensus::CheckTxInputs later (which should be checked before doing any policy checks about inputs, see #6445 ).

If it returns minRelayTxFee, you're just repeating the check that is done a few lines later (`if (nFees < ::minRelayTxFee.GetFee(nSize))`).
